claim: People in Japan are richer than people in Mexico.

supporting.text: Japan has a higher GDP per capita than Mexico, indicating greater average individual wealth.

attacks.text: Japan has a higher GDP per capita than Mexico, indicating greater average individual wealth.
GDP per capita does not account for wealth inequality, which may be higher in Japan, meaning many Japanese could be poorer than the average Mexican.
Japan has a relatively low Gini coefficient compared to Mexico, suggesting wealth is more evenly distributed in Japan.
Cost of living is significantly higher in Japan, so higher nominal GDP per capita may not translate to higher purchasing power or quality of life.
Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show Japan still has higher real income per capita than Mexico.
Mexico has a large informal economy not captured in GDP statistics, potentially understating actual wealth.
Even accounting for informal activity, Japan's formal economy is so much larger that the per capita difference remains substantial.

supporting.text: The median household income in Japan is significantly higher than in Mexico.

attacks.text: The median household income in Japan is significantly higher than in Mexico.
Median income does not account for cost of living differences, which are higher in Japan than in Mexico.
Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that Japanese households have greater real purchasing power despite higher costs.
Income inequality in Japan is higher than in Mexico, so median income may not reflect typical wealth distribution.
Gini coefficient data shows Japan's income inequality is actually lower than Mexico's, supporting the median income comparison.

supporting.text: Japan has a lower poverty rate compared to Mexico, suggesting broader wealth distribution.

attacks.text: Japan has a lower poverty rate compared to Mexico, suggesting broader wealth distribution.
Poverty rate alone does not account for absolute wealth levels; Japan's cost of living is significantly higher, which may offset income advantages.
Even with higher costs, Japan's median disposable income is substantially greater than Mexico's, reinforcing the original claim.
Mexico's informal economy is large and unmeasured, potentially underestimating actual wealth among its population.
Informal economies typically generate lower and less stable incomes, so their exclusion likely strengthens rather than weakens Japan's relative wealth position.

supporting.text: Mexico has a higher Gini coefficient than Japan, indicating greater income inequality and fewer wealthy individuals relative to the population.

attacks.text: Mexico has a higher Gini coefficient than Japan, indicating greater income inequality and fewer wealthy individuals relative to the population.
Gini coefficient measures inequality, not absolute wealth. Japan could still have higher median income despite lower inequality.
Even with higher median income, Japan's lower inequality means wealth is more evenly distributed, potentially making more people 'richer' in relative terms.
Mexico has a larger informal economy, which isn't fully captured by Gini coefficient, potentially underestimating wealth among some groups.
Informal economy workers typically earn less than formal sector workers, so their inclusion would likely show even greater inequality in Mexico.

supporting.text: Japan's social welfare system and public services are more developed, contributing to higher disposable income for its citizens.

attacks.text: Japan's social welfare system and public services are more developed, contributing to higher disposable income for its citizens.
Mexico has a lower cost of living, which can result in higher purchasing power for its citizens despite lower nominal incomes.
Japan's high cost of living, including housing and healthcare, can offset the benefits of higher disposable income.
Income inequality in Japan is significant, and many citizens do not benefit equally from the developed welfare system.
Japan's progressive taxation and social programs actively work to reduce income inequality compared to Mexico.

supporting.text: The cost of living in Japan is higher than in Mexico, but average wages still result in greater purchasing power for Japanese citizens.

attacks.text: The cost of living in Japan is higher than in Mexico, but average wages still result in greater purchasing power for Japanese citizens.
Average wages in Japan have stagnated in recent years, while Mexico has seen wage growth, reducing the purchasing power gap.
Japan's wage stagnation is offset by lower inflation rates compared to Mexico, preserving relative purchasing power.
Regional disparities in Japan mean rural areas have significantly lower purchasing power than urban centers, skewing the national average.
Mexico also has severe regional economic disparities, so the comparison remains valid at the national level.
